book.title: Basic Framework
book.content:
Introduction
Imageview 6 was designed with a flexible way of skinning in mind.
This means it can be customized to match your web site, give it your own theme, make a very dynamic Windows-like gui...

By default 2 templates are provided: Professional & Classic.
While Classic is meant to be a light weight skin that loads quickly, Professional was made to provide a nice and clean interface at the cost of taking a few seconds longer to load.

In the this little guide I'll try to cover the following:
  • Creating A Template
  • Basic Element Placement
  • Basic CSS classes and ID's you'll be interested in
You can find a full reference of all object, classes, ID's & Hooks in the Extended Reference.
Creating A Template
Before you start writing code for your template... we must set up the base for it.
  1. Create an empty text file /imageview6/system/skins/{skin_name}/skin.xml
    {skin_name} should be replaced with the name of your skin.
  2. Create the base XML structure for the template.
    Replace {your_name}, {your_site} & {description} with the correct values. Replace {pb_color} with either
    black, red, orange, blue, green or purple.
    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="iso-8859-1"?>
    <imageview>
       <skin>
          <information>
             <author>{your_name}</author>
             <url>{your_site}</url>
             <version>1.0</version>
             <description>
                <![CDATA[{description}]]>
             </description>
          </information>
          <progressbar>{pb_color}</progressbar>
          <layout>
             <![CDATA[{your_layout}]]>
          </layout>
       </skin>
    </imageview>
  3. You are now ready to start creating the layout.
Basic Element Placement
There are a few elements that must always be present:
  • Album Selector (Treeview or Dropdown)
  • Content Container
Without these elements Imageview would be useless.

All the xhtml code for the layout will go inside the {your_layout} block of skin.xml.
There are some predefined variables that will be replace with the correct code:
  • %base% :: This will be replaced by the URI of your skin folder.
  • %album_dropdown% :: A dropdown list with all groups and albums will be inserted here.
  • %album_tree% :: Same as above, but a treeview instead of a dropdown (note: use only one at a time)
  • %content% :: The content frame will be inserted here.
Using %content% isn't recommended, instead place a div with the id of iContent in your code.
<div id="iContent">
    
</div>
Now start experimenting around with those variables in the {your_layout} portion.
Basic CSS classes and ID's you'll be interested in
Once you got either a Treeview or Dropdown for the album selection and the Content Container on the page,
You probebly want to move it around, give it a more personalized look,...

I'll show you how to attach a style sheet and the basic ID's and Classes to use in your style sheet.
To do so add the following line above the <layout> tag:
<!-- Include for all browsers -->
<style file="general.css" />
<!-- Include for Internet Explorer 5.5 and 6 -->
<style file="iefixes.css" IEHack="True" />
As you have probably noticed... if you add the IEHack="True" attribute the style tag, it will only be included for Internet Explorer 5.5 & 6 (not for version 7).
An attribute media can also be added it works the same way as in html

Here is a list of classes and ID's that you need to change:
  • #iContent :: This is the parent div that holds all output of imageview (except album Dropdown & Tree).
  • #iHeader :: This is a child div of #iContent and holds the description and controle box.
  • #iThumbnailContainer :: This is a child div of #iContent and holds the thumbnails.
  • #iImage :: This is a child div of #iContent and holds the image.
You should have enough information to create basic skins. However for a full reference on the classes, ID's, javascript hooks, object exposed to javascript check out the Extended Reference.

book.title: Extended Reference
book.content:
Introduction
Here you'll find a complete reference on the available CSS classes and ID's, Javascript Hooks and Objects.
With this information, you should be able to create completely customized templates.
  • skin.xml
    • Template
    • Variables
  • Style Sheets
  • Javascript
    • Hooks
    • Exposed Objects
skin.xml Template
All you need to do is replace the values that are bold.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="iso-8859-1"?>
<imageview>
   <skin>
      <information>
         <author>{your_name}</author>
         <url>{your_site}</url>
         <version>1.0</version>
         <description>
            <![CDATA[{description}]]>
         </description>
      </information>
      <progressbar>{pb_color}</progressbar>
      <layout>
         <![CDATA[{your_layout}]]>
      </layout>
   </skin>
</imageview>
{pb_color} can be one of the following: black, red, orange, blue, green or purple
skin.xml Variables
These variables are available to be used inside skin.xml.
  • %base% :: This will be replaced by the URI of your skin folder.
  • %album_dropdown% :: A dropdown list with all groups and albums will be inserted here.
  • %album_tree% :: Same as above, a tree instead of a dropdown (note: only one of them can be used at once)
  • %content% :: The content frame will be inserted here.
Experts Only: It's also posible to provided some of the elements listed below yourself.
Style sheets
Below you will find a complete list of CSS classes and ID's
  • Document Element
    • #iAlbumSelect :: select element :: The album Dropdown
    • #iContent :: div element :: Root element that will hold all output Imageview Generates
      • #iHeader :: div element :: The header that holds description, control box...
        • #iDescription :: div element :: Holds the description of an album
        • #iImageInfo :: div element :: Holds the name & description of an image
          • #iImgName :: span element :: Holds the name of the image
            • .label :: span element :: Holds the label
            • .text :: span element :: Holds the text
          • #iImgDesc :: span element :: Holds the description of the image
            • .label :: span element :: Holds the label
            • .text :: span element :: Holds the text
        • #iControle :: div element :: Holds the buttons to navigate between images, rss icons, ...
      • #iThumbnailContainer :: div element :: Holds the thumbnails
        • .thumbnail :: div element :: The thumbnail box
          • .thumbnail div :: div element :: The inside of the box that holds the image
          • .thumbnail:hover div :: div element :: Same as above but during mouse over
          • .thumbnail span :: span element :: The lable of the thumbnail
      • #iImage :: div element :: Holds the image or loading form
        • .frmLoadImage :: div element :: Loading form
      • .frmAuth :: div element :: Auth form
        • .frmAuth #iAuthTitle :: div element :: Header of the auth form
        • .frmAuth #iAuthContent :: div element :: Window background of the auth form
        • .txtAuthPw :: input element :: Password box on the auth form
        • .chRemember :: input element :: Checkbox on the auth form
        • .cmdAuth :: input element :: Login button on the auth
Javascript Hooks
Below are the Javascript Hooks that can be used:
  • init_skin(oImageview)1 :: Executes right after oImageview has been initialized
  • AlbumLoaded_skin() :: Executes after an album is loaded
  • ImageLoaded_skin() :: Executes after an image is loaded
1 oImageview gets passed as a variable for init_skin, oImageview isn't globaly accessble yet at this stage.

To use one of them, simple create a function in javascript with that name and Imageview will execute it for you.
<script type="text/javascript">
   function init_skin(oImageview){
      //your code here
   }
</script>
Javascript Exposed Objects
Here is a list of the objects Imageview Exposes:
  • oImageview ::
    • skin :: Skin properties
      • rssIcon :: Path to the RSS icon
      • keyIcon :: Path to the icon displayed on the Auth form
      • uploadIcon :: Path to the upload icon
      • slideIcon :: Path to the start slideshow icon
      • slideIcon_disabled :: Path to the stop slideshow icon
      • prevIcon :: Path to the previous icon
      • prevIcon_disabled :: Path to the disabled previous icon
      • upIcon :: Path to the up lever icon (return to album)
      • nextIcon :: Path to the next cion
      • nextIcon_disabled :: Path to the disabled next icon
      • progressBar :: Path to the progressbar that is displayed while loading an image
    • browser :: Bowser Information
      • userAgent :: Browser's name e.g. 'Internet Explorer', 'Opera', 'Mozilla'
      • version :: Browser's verion number
    • state :: Information on the current state of Imageview
      • album :: currently loaded album
      • image :: currently loaded image (empty if viewing album)
      • locked :: true if the album is locked (false if album is unlocked or not protected)
      • nextImg :: the next image (only if browsing through image, empty during slideshow or album view)
      • prevImg :: the previous image (only if browsing through image, empty during slideshow or album view)
    • LoadAdmin() :: Loads the administrator interface
    • LoadHelp() :: Loads the documentation
  • webFXTreeConfig :: Tree Properties
    • folderIcon :: Path to group icon
    • openFolderIcon :: Path to open group icon
    • fileIcon :: Path to album icon
You can use them to overwrite the default icons, do browser specific corrections:
<script type="text/javascript">
   function init_skin(oImageview){
      //use costume RSS icon
      oImageview.skin.rssIcon = '%base%/images/icons/rss.png';
      if(oImageview.browser.userAgent == "Internet Explorer"){
         if(oImageview.browser.version < 7){
            //we are using IE6 or lower
         }
      }
   }
</script>
